BUILD ALTERNATIVE COMPARISON
    The proposed development will generate less traffic than the Religious Use or Workforce
Housing Alternatives. The Workforce Housing and Religious Use Alternatives will have a
greater impact on the level of service and delays on the roadway network surrounding the subject
site.




                                             - 132 -
                                      CONCLUSIONS
   In summary, the proposed project will redevelop the existing single family home located at
100 Clover Drive and construct 11-single family homes along a private roadway and cul-de-sac. The
private roadway will intersect with Clover Drive west of Middle Neck Road.

   Parking is provided for each of the 12-single family homes. Each home will have a private
driveway leading to an attached two car garage. The number of parking spaces provided meets the
requirements of the Village of Great Neck and Great Neck Estates.

   The private roadway and cul-de-sac have been designed in accordance with standard engineering
practices. The private roadway will provide two-way traffic flow via one 13-foot lane in each
direction. Pedestrian access is provided via a five foot sidewalk. The home located at 100 Clover
Drive will continue to have access on Clover Drive. The other homes will have individual driveways
connecting to the private roadway.

   The site is anticipated to generate a maximum of 19-trips during the evening peak hour
(11-entering and 8-exiting the site). As these trips are distributed through the roadway network
the potential impact becomes de minimis. One vehicle is equivalent to approximately 9% of the
entering traffic and 12% of the exiting traffic.

   During the peak hour the proposed site is anticipated to generate less then 1-entering trip
every 5-minutes and 1-exiting trip every 7-minutes. This equates to less than 1-trip every
3-minutes entering or exiting the site.

   The traffic signals along Middle Neck Road have a cycle length of approximately
60-seconds. Cycle length refers to the time required for one complete sequence of all signal
indications. The total site generated traffic would add 1-vehicle during the course of 3-complete
cycle lengths.

   The level of traffic generated by the subject site will have no perceptible impact to the level
of service on the surrounding roadway network.




                                                   - 133 -
    The applicant is proposing two potential mitigation measures to address existing traffic issues
on Clover Drive. The first mitigation measure would be to restrict left turn movements from
Clover Drive during the pm peak hour from 4:00pm to 6:00pm. This mitigation measure is
presented due to the existing delay experience by vehicles turning left from Clover Drive onto
Middle Neck Road. Although these vehicles need to wait approximately 50-seconds we do not
believe this is a safety issue. The accident history at this intersection does not support the need
for this restriction.

    The finding of our sight distance analysis show that the proposed roadway meets the
recommended guidelines provided by the American Association of State Highway and
Transportation Officials (AASHTO), Guidelines for Geometric Design of Very Low-Volume
Local Roads (ADT400), 2001.

    The second mitigation measure relates to the safety of motorist and pedestrians on Clover
Drive. As part of the construction of the project the applicant proposes to install a series of
warning signs and advisory speed plaques related to the vertical grade change and limited sight
distance along Clover Drive. If approved the applicant would be responsible for the cost
associated with these improvements.

    The proposed development will generate less traffic than the Religious Use or Workforce
Housing Alternatives. The Workforce Housing and Religious Use Alternatives will have a
greater impact on the level of service and delays on the roadway network surrounding the subject
site.




                                               - 134 -

Section 2C.18 HILL BLOCKS VIEW Sign (W7-6)
   Option:
01     $+,//%/2&.69,(::VLJQVHH)LJXUH&PD\EHXVHGLQDGYDQFHRIDFUHVWYHUWLFDOFXUYHWR
   advise road users to reduce speed as they approach and traverse the hill as only limited stopping sight distance is
   available.
   Guidance:
02     :KHQD+,//%/2&.69,(:VLJQLVXVHGLWVKRXOGEHVXSSOHPHQWHGE\DQ$GYLVRU\6SHHG:-3SODTXH
   indicating the recommended speed for traveling over the hillcrest based on available stopping sight distance.
Section 2C.19 ROAD NARROWS Sign (W5-1)
   Guidance:
01    ([FHSWDVSURYLGHGLQ3DUDJUDSKD52$'1$552:6:VLJQVHH)LJXUH&VKRXOGEHXVHGLQ
   advance of a transition on two-lane roads where the pavement width is reduced abruptly to a width such that
   vehicles traveling in opposite directions cannot simultaneously travel through the narrow portion of the roadway
   without reducing speed.
   Option:
02    7KH52$'1$552:6:VLJQPD\EHRPLWWHGRQORZYROXPHORFDOVWUHHWVWKDWKDYHVSHHGOLPLWVRI
   30 mph or less.
03    $GGLWLRQDOHPSKDVLVPD\EHSURYLGHGE\WKHXVHRIREMHFWPDUNHUVDQGGHOLQHDWRUVVHH6HFWLRQV%WKURXJK
   %DQG&KDSWHU)7KH$GYLVRU\6SHHG:3SODTXHVHH6HFWLRQ&PD\EHXVHGWRLQGLFDWHWKH
   recommended speed.




     December 2009                                                                                      Sect. 2C.17 to 2C.19
     2009 Edition                                                                                                      Page 109

04     Minimum spacing between warning signs with different messages should be based on the estimated PRT for
   driver comprehension of and reaction to the second sign.
05     The effectiveness of the placement of warning signs should be periodically evaluated under both day and
   night conditions.
   Option:
06     :DUQLQJVLJQVWKDWDGYLVHURDGXVHUVDERXWFRQGLWLRQVWKDWDUHQRWUHODWHGWRDVSHFL픃ORFDWLRQVXFKDV'HHU
   Crossing or SOFT SHOULDER, may be installed in an appropriate location, based on engineering judgment, since
   they are not covered in Table 2C-4.

                                                     Reference Notes
              Off-Peak one way/ten trip tickets not honored. Senior citizen/People with disabilities/Medicare customers tickets not
PEAK AM       honored (restriction lifted on Columbus, Election & Veterans Days). No bicycles are allowed on these trains.

              Off-Peak one way/ten trip tickets not honored. At stations other than western terminals, PM Peak trains may leave
PEAK PM       up to three minutes early. Please allow sufficient time. No bicycles are allowed on these trains.

              Train runs March 17, April 18, 19 & 22, May 27, July 1, September 2 & 28, October 7, November 23, December 23 &
 Hol Eve      30, 2011
              Holiday service will operate on New Year's Day, Presidents' Day, Memorial Day, July 4th (Independence Day), Labor
              Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day. Regular weekday service will operate on the day after Thanksgiving.
 Holidays     A Modified Holiday schedule will operate on Martin Luther King, Jr. Day. Off Peak fares will apply on these days.
              Senior/Disabled/Medicare tickets will be honored all day on Columbus Day, Election Day and Veterans Day.
              Bicycles will not be permitted on all holidays noted above as well as: St. Patrick's Day, Mother's Day, Good
              Friday, Easter Sunday, the Friday before Memorial & Labor Days, the weekday before Independence Day (and the
              designated Federal Day off), the Eves of Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur, Thanksgiving Eve, Christmas Eve, New
              Year's Eve, and any other NYC parades, or major Long Island bike events. Call Public Affairs (718) 217-5477 or see
              online Bike Policy for details.
              Mets-Willets Point is located between Woodside and Flushing Main Street and is served seasonally for special
   Note       events. Special Mets-Willets Point timetables showing this service are published during the baseball season and for
              the U.S. Open Tennis event.
              For complete service at Woodside please consult the City Terminal Zone Timetable. Eastbound trains from
   Note       Woodside to Port Washington depart on Platform B.
